perturbation.original_text: 1.7      "Defect" shall mean any failure of Licensed Technology to meet the Specification as a result of a material failure (including an error or "bug" that is material) of the Licensed Technology. "Material" is defined as priority A, B, and C in Article 6.3.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.7      "Defect" shall mean any failure of Licensed Technology to meet the Specification as a result of any failure (including an error or "bug") of the Licensed Technology. "Material" is defined as priority A in Article 6.3.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of 'Defect' includes failures resulting from 'material' errors, and defines 'Material' as priority A, B, and C in Article 6.3. The modified definition broadens the scope of 'Defect' by including any failure, regardless of its materiality, and restricts the definition of 'Material' to only priority A defects, contradicting the original intention and creating uncertainty about which failures qualify as Defects and what recourse Licensee has.

perturbation.original_text:
6.3      Error Correction. If D2 becomes aware of any Defect in the Licensed Technology, D2 shall promptly provide LICENSEE with written notice of such Defect. D2 shall have no obligation to actively monitor the Licensed Technology for Defects after such software has been accepted by LICENSEE. D2 shall work diligently to promptly correct Defects in accordance with the following schedule; "days" shall mean calendar days.

      ERROR PRIORITY (1)         RESPONSE (2)      CLOSURE (3)

      Emergency (A)              24 hours          7 days

      Critical (B)               2 days            14 days

      Non-Critical (C)           30 days           Next Update                                                       or                                                       New Version

               (1)      Priority:

                        -A-      Catastrophic product or module Defects that do not have a viable detour or work around available.

                        -B-      Defects  that have been  substantiated  as a serious inconvenience to LICENSEE or an End User. This includes any priority A Defect for which a viable detour or work around is available.

                        -C-      All other problems that LICENSEE and an End User can easily avoid for which there is no urgency for a resolution.
perturbation.changed_text:
6.3      Error Correction. If D2 becomes aware of any Defect in the Licensed Technology, D2 may at its discretion provide LICENSEE with written notice of such Defect. D2 shall have no obligation to actively monitor the Licensed Technology for Defects after such software has been accepted by LICENSEE. D2 shall work to correct Defects in accordance with the following schedule; "days" shall mean business days.

      ERROR PRIORITY (1)         RESPONSE (2)      CLOSURE (3)

      Emergency (A)              24 hours          7 days

      Critical (B)               5 days            30 days

      Non-Critical (C)           60 days           As Available

               (1)      Priority:

                        -A-      Catastrophic product or module Defects that do not have a viable detour or work around available.

                        -B-      Defects  that have been  substantiated  as a serious inconvenience to LICENSEE or an End User. This includes any priority A Defect for which a viable detour or work around is available.

                        -C-      All other problems that LICENSEE and an End User can easily avoid for which there is no urgency for a resolution.
perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates D2 to provide written notice of defects and diligently correct them according to a strict schedule. The modified text introduces ambiguity by giving D2 the discretion to provide notice and altering the correction schedule to be less stringent (changing calendar days to business days, increasing response and closure times, and changing "Next Update or New Version" to "As Available"). This creates a contradiction, as the original text implies a guaranteed level of error correction service, while the new language allows D2 to potentially delay or avoid these obligations, introducing uncertainty in enforcement.

perturbation.original_text:
8.3      Software Warranty. D2 warrants to LICENSEE that the media upon which the Licensed Technology is delivered to LICENSEE will be free from Defects in materials and workmanship, and that Licensed Technology shall meet and perform in accordance with D2's specifications on Exhibit A. D2 shall promptly correct any

Software License                                           D2 Technologies, Inc. and Maintenance Agreement       August 4, 1997                      CONFIDENTIAL

12

errors in the Licensed Technology, or failures of the Licensed Technology according to the terms of Article 6 of this Agreement. D2's warranty and error correction obligations with respect to any portion of the Licensed Technology shall extend for a period (the "Warranty period") of one year commencing on acceptance of such portion of the Licensed Technology by LICENSEE.
perturbation.changed_text: 8.3      Software Warranty. D2 warrants to LICENSEE that the media upon which the Licensed Technology is delivered to LICENSEE will be free from Defects in materials and workmanship, and that Licensed Technology shall substantially meet and generally perform in accordance with D2's high-level intentions regarding specifications on Exhibit A. D2 shall endeavor to correct errors in the Licensed Technology, or failures of the Licensed Technology as D2 reasonably determines according to the terms of Article 6 of this Agreement. D2's warranty and error correction obligations with respect to any portion of the Licensed Technology shall extend for a period (the "Warranty period") of 90 days commencing 30 days after delivery of such portion of the Licensed Technology to LICENSEE.
perturbation.explanation: The original warranty provides a firm commitment that the Licensed Technology will meet the specifications and any errors will be promptly corrected with obligations extending for one year from acceptance. The modified warranty weakens the specifications requirement to 'substantially meet' with performance according to D2's 'high-level intentions', changes the error correction obligation to a discretionary 'endeavor', and reduces the warranty period to 90 days, starting 30 days AFTER delivery, thus potentially reducing the actual warranty coverage time. This creates a conflict regarding the standard of performance and the duration of the warranty, leading to uncertainty about D2's obligations and LICENSEE's rights.
